content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the payoff structure, it seems like the optimal strategy here would be to choose R (R_{you}) since the reward for choosing R when they pick B (40$) is higher than the reward for choosing B when they pick R (20$).

However, if we consider a mixed strategy where we randomly choose between R and B in each round, it could potentially lead to a higher average payoff. Since the game has 75 rounds, even a slight edge in our strategy could result in a significant difference over time.

But remember, the opponent is anonymous, so they don't know or adapt to our strategy. In this case, since we believe that our opponent might choose randomly, it would still be beneficial to stick with R most of the time due to the higher payoff when our opponent picks B.

So, considering these factors, I will make my choice as R_{you}. However, keep in mind that if our opponent consistently chooses R, a mixed strategy might lead to better results over 75 rounds. But since we don't know their strategy, sticking with R seems reasonable based on the available information.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

After observing that my opponent chooses B when I chose R, it might be beneficial to consider a mixed strategy for future rounds. This way, I can increase my chances of earning a higher payoff if the opponent continues to choose B when I pick R.

So, in this next round, I will choose R with probability 0.5 and B with probability 0.5 (R_{you}, mixed strategy).
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent chose R when I picked B, it suggests that they might be more likely to choose R in future rounds as well. In this case, sticking with a mixed strategy could still potentially lead to a higher average payoff over time.

So, for the next round, I will continue to use the same mixed strategy where I choose R with probability 0.5 and B with probability 0.5 (B_{you}, mixed strategy).
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.
